This rondo variation is played with two teams. When one team loses the ball or maintains possession for a given amount of time, a new ball starts on the opposite side. It’s a fun spin on a traditional 4v2 rondo because the teams can compete against eachother to try to earn points and win.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version=”3.25″][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_video src=”https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CjWPDqWZnqE&t=2s” _builder_version=”3.22.7″][/et_pb_video][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][et_pb_row _builder_version=”3.25″][et_pb_column type=”4_4″ _builder_version=”3.25″ custom_padding=”|||” custom_padding__hover=”|||”][et_pb_image src=”https://ts-uploads.azureedge.net/marketing/2019/07/4v2-transitional-Rondo.png” align=”center” align_tablet=”center” align_last_edited=”on|desktop” _builder_version=”3.23″ max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop”][/et_pb_image][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center”]

Set Up

Create a rectangular grid divided into halves to form two playing areas as shown in the diagram above. In addition, two teams of four players are needed for this drill. One team of four starts on one side of the grid against two of the opposing players who will be defending them. The other two players stand by on the opposite side of the grid.

Having a supply of balls close by is nice to minimize down time in case a ball goes out of play. 

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center”]

How It Works

This drill starts with a 4v2 rondo ‘keep away’ on one side which can be initiated by a coach playing a ball into the area or the players can start the drill on their own. The offensive players try to maintain possession of the ball for a certain amount of time or a complete a minimum number of passes to earn a point. Meanwhile the two defenders are working to win the ball back.

In the event that the defensive players win the ball, the offensive team earns a point, or the ball goes out of play, a new ball starts on the opposite side. The two players who were defending join their two teammates for a 4v2 advantage against two defenders on the opposite side.

[/et_pb_text][et_pb_text _builder_version=”3.27.4″ text_font=”|300|||||||” text_text_color=”#151516″ max_width=”70%” max_width_tablet=”” max_width_phone=”” max_width_last_edited=”on|desktop” module_alignment=”center”]

Coaching Points

In general rondos are great to help players work on keeping possession of the ball and improve basic passing skills. In addition, this drill teaches players to quickly react to changes in possession and transition to the opposite side if the ball goes out of play.

The difficulty of this exercise can be modified by limiting the number of touches players can take or changing the size of the grid.

[/et_pb_text][/et_pb_column][/et_pb_row][/et_pb_section]
